This project will support 98,754 people through targeted approach. 1938 HHs (11,628 people) will be provided with foodassistance through cash intervention, 35,000 people will have access to safe drinking water through water pointsrehabilitation. To improve safe hygiene practices and ensure preventive measures to reduce exposure to COVID-19risk total 98,754 people will be reached through blended public health promotion activities, which would becomplimented with hygiene kit distribution to most vulnerable6000 HHs (36,000 people). 800 HHs will beprovided with emergency shelter kit that would benefit 4800 people.

participating-org.narrative:
In 2008, various Oxfams in India joined forces to form Oxfam India. Registered as an independent organisation, Oxfam India has indigenous staff and board members. We are a member of the global confederation of 20 Oxfams.
We focus on four poverty eliminating goals
1: Livelihood: More women and men will realise their right to secure and sustainable livelihoods. 2: Fight for women: More women will lead a violence-free life. This can be achieved through changes in attitudes and beliefs about gender relations and through encouraging women's engagement and assuming leadership in institutions and decision-making roles. 3: Education and Health: People living in poverty, especially women and, girls will realise their right to accessible and affordable healthcare, education, clean water and sanitation. 4: Human Rights: Those facing a humanitarian crisis will be assured the protection and the assistance they need, regardless of who they are, where they live or how they are affected.
We see poverty as a problem of power, the lack of power.’ We workwith 60 NGOs at the grassroots’ level to tackle poverty and inequality where it germinates. Our programmes are currently active in the critical states of Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Odisha and Uttar Pradesh. We work with the most marginalised segments – Dalits, Tribals, Muslims, and Women. For them, poverty is more than lack of income, healthcare and education. It is a crippling state where these groups do not have any control in deciding the course of their own lives. They are excluded from basic decision-making rights.
Oxfam works primarily through grassroots organisations to bring deep-rooted sustainable changes in people’s lives. We do this through long-term development programming and link it to positive policy changes at various levels. We work for the socially excludedand most marginalised communities by mobilising them to campaign for greater economic and social reforms. We use our learnings about what works and what doesn’t at the grassroots level, through research and advocacy, to bring about pro-poor changes in policies and institutions.

The project aims to promote civic activism in protecting freedom of expression during and after the COVID-19 pandemic, and in taking part in government-led pandemic response. This project addresses these challenges by strengthening Vietnamese CSO networks nationwide in their capacity to mount coordinated actions to participate effectively in the government-led COVID-19 response, targeting thepopulation most in need; and, by enhancing their capacity to influence respect for privacy rights and respect forfreedom of expression. The project is developed with active participation from leading civil society partners, including CSOs networks defending humanrights and promoting inclusive social protection. Overall Objective: Civil society will become an effective force for defence of human rights during the COVID-19 crisis, in expanding freedom of expression and participation in government-led recovery programs.

participating-org.narrative: In Vietnam , Oxfam is one of the leading international, non -governmental organisation. Since 1955, Oxfam is active in Vietnam withhumanitarian interventions and started development work in the late 1980's. Today, Oxfam works in 26 provinces with people, governments and civil society to promote equality and well-being through social and economic change.

participating-org.narrative: Center for Education Promotion and CEPEW

Center for Education Promotion and Empowerment of Women (CEPEW) is a Vietnamese Non-governmental organization established in 1997. Promotion and protection women human rights in particular and human right , universal values in general and enabling civilsociety environment are two of CEPEW#s priorities. So that, CEPEW is an active member of People#s Participation Working Group, Cooperation Group for Governance and Administration Reform (GPAR) and Gender and Community Development Network (GENCOMNET). In recent years, CEPEWhas coordinated hundreds civil society organizations to develop join submission on human rights implementation in Vietnam under Universal Periodic Review Mechanism of UN Human Rights Council and stakeholders# report on implementation ofConvention on Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) and presented it to CEDAW Committee in Geneva. CEPEW has also applied international human rights standards and universal values for policy advocacy in Vietnam.

Oxfam has prepared the COVID-19 Response Strategy based on the needs, gaps, sectoral priority and organisational capacity. All humanitarian actors in country are making all the efforts to meet the life-saving emergency needs of people of Afghanistan and still fall short of achieving the minimum target due to shortage of funds. Last year the funding fell short by 75.2%, as per the current HRP.WASH is a key focus for Oxfam along with Emergency Food Security and Protection. Herat and Daykundi are priority provinces for Oxfam in Afghanistan. This project is designed in alignment to this Response strategy and HRP. In both provinces, Oxfam has extended presence and various other projects. Proposed project will link with other ongoing projects that have explicit focus on GBV/VAW, staff will collaborate and link with sector specialist staff as and when needed. This can take form of Psycho-social counselling and psycho-social support services, in Women Friendly Health Spaces that are already established in bothprovinces. In addition, where possible, Mobile Outreach Units will be available, they travel to the communities and raise awareness and link protection specific cases toconcerned organisation or service provider. Technical expert staff members of Protection/GBV project will provide orientation to staff members of this project so that they can understand the issue and its sensitivity, able to identify protection concerns and properly inform right persons considering the sensitivity and confidentiality ofthe issue. This project will directly benefit at least 3328,000 women, men, girls and boys in 4 districts of Daykundi and Herat province of Afghanistan - Miramor district in Daykundi, and Koshk-e-Robat Sangi, Enjil, Zindajan and Ghoriyan districts of Herat province.
Hygiene Kits (see below in the text for the kit contents) and awareness sessions to female and male members of targeted households (HHs) will ensure that they follow the minimum hygiene practices and keep themselves safe from the deadly virus as well as other water and vector borne diseases. Support provided to theWASH Committees in the localities will ensure that the communal water points remain clean and hygienic and keeps the community safe. This will directly benefit 28,000 women, men,girls and boys of 4,000 HHs and also some WASH Committees in their community.
Household (HH) level Hygiene Kits: the project will distribute kits as per Afghanistan WASH Cluster standards and recommendations and adapted to local context and culture.The kits contain 7 Bathing Soaps (250gm each), 7 Laundry Soaps (200g each), 2 Plastic Soap Case, 2 Plastic Jerrican (Rigit, 10 Ltr each), 1 Ewer (Aftaba as household handwashing tool, 2 Ltr), 2 Packets of Sanitary Pads (Normal, 10 pcs in each packet) and1 printed COVID-19 Awareness Message (IEC material in local languages for COVID-19 in line with MoPH, WHO andUNICEF guidance). Oxfam office in Herat and ADA in Daykundi will follow all the norms of coordination for selection of communities considering vulnerability, exposure to risks and action of other actors in the district. HHs will be selected following a transparent and participatory manner by engaging the community people and following the basic selection criteria as practiced by all WASH Actors in Afghanistan. Door to door survey or remote survey will be used considering the risk level of the pandemic, digital data will be collected using HEAT and will be analysed for selection and recording of the community data. Selected HHs will be informed tocomeand collect the items from a distribution point. Oxfam/ADA will try to take the distribution point as close to the community as they can. Women or child-headed households, households with aged or people with disability and also more number of children will be prioritized for selecting for this intervention. The Hygiene Kit is designed by the WASH Cluster considering the needs of women and adolescent girls in the society.
Hygiene Awareness Session: 1 female and 1 male member from each of the HHs receiving the Hygiene Kits will be invited to participate a session in local language by local staff members. This session will contain general hygiene practice, water safety, COVID-19 awareness, dos and don’ts for general water safety, hygiene practice and COVID-19. IEC material in local language will be used for these sessions which was developed by WASH Cluster for Afghanistan and also the one developed with COVID-19messages. Each session will have only 10 men or 10 women considering the cultural practice of Afghanistan and COVID-19 guidelines. This will ensure that at least 50% of the people attending the awareness sessions are women. This will have impact on carrying the good messages to the children of all the households better. On the other hand this will encourage better participatory decision making in the families.
WASH Committees: will be formed with 5 women and 5 men from the community. They will be given orientation on personal, household and environmental hygiene practice and will be given responsibility to follow-up with their respective community that it is maintained. This will be their proactive and voluntary service to the community and in previous programmes was found to have good impact on sustainable service in the community beyond the project duration.
Hygiene Kits for WASH Committees: this is a special package designed in consultation with a number of existing WASH Committee Members (with 50% women representatives) in different rural communities where Oxfam is already working. This will be given to each WASH Committee formed and/or oriented under this project so that they can use these to keep their Communal Water Points clean and safe for all the community members using them. This will contain 15 Kg of bleaching powder, 15 Ltr of Disinfection liquid, 1 Spray Pump, 4 brooms, 3 pairs of Heavy-duty Rubber Gloves, 1 box(100 pcs) Surgical Masks, 6 bottle of hand sanitizer (400ml each) and 2 pairs of Rubber Boots. WHO guideline for disinfection efforts in Afghanistan gives priority to disinfecting health facilities and also indicated environmental cleaning in community places, this will be used for that purpose. Afghanistan WASH Committee encouraged this new package proposed by Oxfam.
Handwashing Stations: Handwashing Stations will be installed in the targeted schools before they re-open, complimented by awareness sessions and specially designed IEC material, to ensure that the students and teachers in the schools will be able to protect themselves from the deadly virus as well asother water and vector borne diseases. This will directly benefit at least 5,000 female and male students and teacher in 10 schools. Oxfam will directly implement this project in Herat while ADA will be implementing it in Daykundi province. 50 students per handwashing station. This is as per the design accepted by the Afghanistan WASH Cluster and will contain locally available items and technology which will be easy for the users to use and maintain. The package will contain a small water tank witheasy-opening tap, a stand at good height for washing hands, supply of soaps for 50 boys and girls for 2 months, and a total of 100 handwashingstations.
Hygiene <(>&<)> COVID-19 Awareness Sessions for Schools: will cover all the schools covered by Handwashing Stations under this project, the total number of schools will be confirmed at a later stage when the schools are identified and they agree for this activity.
IEC for Students: Oxfam/ADA Hygiene Promoters will use local IEC materials designed by WASHCluster and orient the student of the schools about water safety, personal hygiene, household hygiene and environmental hygiene practice, dos and don’ts for COVID-19, misperceptions related to COVID-19. Students will be encouraged to wash their hands every day when entering the school. s. IEC will be in a workbook format (note book for practice and working) with the covers printed with Hygiene and COVID-19 awareness messages. These will spread the health and hygiene messages to the community and will retain forlonger time in front of their eyes to remind them practice and make it their habit.
Despite not having specific budget or related Output targets, this project will also do the following: - Demonstrate good practice of women and men working together and learning together for betterment of the society as a whole - Sensitize more staff members as well as community leaders, including both women and men from the communities, about women claiming their rights and contributing to the society. - Theprojectwill keep an eye on the Protection concerns and PSEA issues andall staff will be trained to report them properly. Staff members of this project will work as change agents for Gender Equity and watchdogs for GBV or Protection Concerns.

participating-org.narrative: The Afghan Development Association (ADA) was established in 1990 with the purpose of improving agricultural productivity in rural Afghanistan. Agricultural areas have suffered considerably as a result of almost 24 years of civil war in the country. Theirrigation system of canals and karezes (small water tunnels), on which large parts of agrarian land depend, were damaged or destroyed, or goneinto disuse after years of neglect. The consequences of the civil war include the displacement of large numbers of people and severe disruption of the economy and livelihoods of numerous poor families. ADA has concentrated its efforts in the southern and western regions of the country. Given the relative security and stability in these areas during Taliban rule,thedisplaced and refugee population of the region has been gradually returning from surrounding areas and countries. The drought prevailing for the last three years has, however, slowed down the repatriation process to some extent. The returning populationis in need of continued support to facilitate their re-integration. ADA has developed a multi-sectoral, integrated rural development package that includes the rehabilitation of irrigation systems, horticulture development, agricultural inputs (such as fertilisers, improved seed varieties, tools), veterinary training, health education, vocational training, and environmental conservation. Oxfam Novib has provided support to ADA for Integrated Rural Development Projects for several years entailing thefollowing aspects of development: encouraging and facilitating return of refugees; rehabilitating and developing rural infrastructure including farm activities; creating employment and livelihood opportunities; facilitating socio-economic reintegration; and ensuring the participation of local communities in the rural rehabilitation activities. Major components covered with Oxfam Novib support have included: the rehabilitation of rural infrastructure; food security; water supply; and vocational training. Theprojects have served tens of thousands of families. All these services were found useful in the direction of accomplishing broader objectives of alleviating poverty and fostering peace in Afghanistan.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam works to help poor and marginalized people to gain control over their own lives by exercising their right to political participation, freedom of expression and information, freedom of assembly, and access to justice. Many projects currently being executed by Oxfam in Afghanistan on women and youth fall under this campaign.
In Afghanistan, ON has been working with local NGOs, civil society organisations and networks through a number of initiatives to raise awareness about human rights, promote women's participation and leadership, and empower citizens to speak out on issues that affect their lives and to improve governance

title.narrative: CRUDAN-Food Sec. & GBV Resp. to COVID-19

description.narrative:
The Christian Rural and Urban Development Association of Nigeria(CRUDAN) is a Christian inter-denominational, not-for-profit, Non-Governmental Organization. It is a membership organization that has as its members-Churches, Christian organizations and individuals that are engaged or interested in development work in Nigeria. It has the main goal of promoting the growth of the church in Nigeriaby assisting in rural/urban development work that is part of her witness. CRUDAN serves the church all over Nigeria in Wholistic development work. CRUDAN was formed in 1990, following the merger of two Christian organizations that operated independently in the country, namely Christian Rural Advisory Council(CRAC), Founded in 1965 in the Northern part of Nigeria, and Christian Rural Fellowshipof Nigeria(CRFN), established in 1953, in the Southern part of Nigeria. Being a membership organization, the members from the general assembly that elects the board. CRUDAN has five(5) zones within the country namely, Central,Northeast, Northwest, Southeast and Southwest zones with a Zonal facilitator and Administrative Assistant for each zone. With this arrangement, CRUDAN is able to effectively cover the whole nation. CRUDAN began operation in 1991 and was officially registered by the Corporate Affairs Commission(CAC) of the Federal Government of Nigeria on 7th December 1992. Registration number 7111.
This project will build on the strengths and lessons learned from previous and ongoing programs led by Oxfam. Specifically, the action will complement the ongoing interventions ofthe EU Support to Food Security and Resilience in Northern Nigeria# (PROACT) in Adamawa and Kebbi states in northern Nigeria. The project is benefiting over 25,000 vulnerable farming households in 80 rural communities, 70% of whom will be women. These Vulnerable households, were in the verypoor and poor categories prior to Oxfam intervention in target locations of this project, and were beginning to attain comfortable positions in terms of food security and livelihoods outcomes before the COVID 19 pandemic struck. These populations are nowat risk of having their strengthened resilience attenuated as a result of COVID-19 pandemic. The project will also use the findings of the recent rapid care analysis conducted in Adamawa and Kebbi address gender based violence issues arising from the Covid 19 pandemic. The power relations which places women as the subordinate gender groups within this society, leaves the women vulnerable to GBV violence, as there is a power imbalance between men and women as highlighted by the RGA will also be addressedby this Project.

participating-org.narrative: Christian Rural and Urban Developme Association of Nigeria

The Christian Rural and Urban Development Association of Nigeria(CRUDAN) is a Christian inter-denominational, not-for-profit, Non-Governmental Organization. It is a membership organization that has as its members-Churches, Christian organizations and individuals that are engaged or interested in development work in Nigeria. It has the main goal of promoting the growth of the church in Nigeriaby assisting in rural/urban development work that is part of her witness. CRUDAN serves the church all over Nigeria in Wholistic development work. CRUDAN was formed in 1990, following the merger of two Christian organizations that operated independently in the country, namely Christian Rural Advisory Council(CRAC), Founded in 1965 in the Northern part of Nigeria, and Christian Rural Fellowship of Nigeria(CRFN), established in 1953, in the Southern part of Nigeria. Being a membership organization, the members from the general assembly that elects the board. CRUDAN has five(5) zones within the country namely, Central,Northeast, Northwest, Southeast and Southwest zones with a Zonal facilitator and Administrative Assistant for each zone. With this arrangement, CRUDAN is able to effectively cover the whole nation. CRUDAN began operation in 1991 and was officially registered by the Corporate Affairs Commission(CAC) of the Federal Government of Nigeria on 7th December 1992. Registration number 7111.

title.narrative: RHDI -Food Sec. & GBV Resp. to COVID-19

description.narrative: Reconnect Health Development Initiative (RHDI) is a not-for-profit, non-government organization headquartered in Nigeria for 6 years to promote awareness of mental health issues, and provide psychological treatment and support services for individuals, groups andcommunities. Working together with relevant stakeholders, we affirm our commitment to support and alleviate the sufferings of persons affected by gender-based violence, disasters, crises, violence, mental health disorders, psychological and substance abuse problems. We believe no one should face a mental health problem alone and we would not give up until everyone in need of psychological support access the support the require. With nearly 50 seasoned professionals comprising of Clinical and Behavioural Psychologists, Educational and Child Psychologists, Consultant Psychiatrists, Public Health Specialists and Counsellors. With our contribution to the psychosocial space is unparalleled. This project will build on the strengths and lessons learned from previous and ongoing programs led by Oxfam. Specifically, the action will complement the ongoing interventions of the EU Support to Food Security and Resilience in Northern Nigeria# (PROACT) in Adamawa and Kebbi states in northern Nigeria. The project is benefiting over 25,000 vulnerable farming households in 80 rural communities, 70% of whom will be women. These Vulnerable households, were in the very poor and poor categories prior to Oxfam intervention in target locations of this project, and were beginning to attain comfortable positions in terms offood security and livelihoods outcomes before the COVID 19 pandemic struck. These populations are now at risk of having their strengthened resilience attenuated as a result of COVID-19 pandemic. The project will also use the findings of the recent rapid care analysis conducted in Adamawa and Kebbi address gender based violence issues arising from the Covid 19 pandemic. The power relations which places women as the subordinate gender groups withinthis society, leaves the women vulnerable to GBV violence, as there is a power imbalance between men and women as highlighted by the RGA will also be addressed by this Project.

participating-org.narrative:
Reconnect Health Development Initiative (RHDI) is an mental health non-profit, non-government organization headquartered in Nigeriasince 2013, to provide psychological treatment and support services to address mental health issues while providing psychological treatment services to people and communities. Working together with relevant stakeholders, we affirm our commitment to support and alleviate the sufferings of persons affected by disasters, mental disorder, psychological and substance abuse problems. We believe no one should face a mental health challenge alone and we would not give up until everyone in need of psychological support access the required.
Reconnect HDI has nearly 50 seasoned professionals comprising of Clinical and Behavioural Psychologists, Educational and Child Psychologists, Consultant Psychiatrists, Public Health Specialists and Counsellors. With our partners from the public, privateand NGO sectors, our contribution to the psychosocial space is unparalleled
Our Objectives are: * To raise awareness and combat stigma on mental illness through culturally appropriate methods. * To care and protect the wellbeing and rights of vulnerable population including survivors of gender based violence. * To promote access and availability of psychosocial and treatment services. * To host research on mental health to inform policies and sustain wellbeing of beneficiaries. * To strengthen partnerships and platforms of support for individuals, communities and groups.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novibs main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fund raising, campaigning and advocacy. The Hub Niamey Niger exists since 2006 as a humanitarian field office and since 2012 as the decentralized Country office for Oxfam Novib, dealing with all the development and humanitarian themes like Sustainable livelihoods, Right to Basic services, Humanitarian and resilience interventions, The right to be heard and the right to an Identity, including women's rights and sexual and reproductive health rights. The Country Office in Niger works with local partners to realize the vision of a Niger without poverty

# Solarization of two existing water sources in Baki and Saylac districts of Awdal benefiting more than 10,000 people and their livestock. Awdal is one of the regions affected by COVID19 as it connects Somaliland to Djibouti. The majority of people are dependent pity trades, small scale irrigation, and livestock, most of these activities have been affected, and communities reported a reduction of income. Existing water supply sources are mainly powered by a diesel generator that are purchased from the tariffs collected from the users. Associated water tariffs are sky rocking as access to diesel has reduced as restrictions are imposed on public transport. Out of the many strategic water sources, two sources are selected, supplying water for villages affected by COVID19 in Somaliland. Oxfam will install a solar system for these wells, and the action will reduce the cost of water tariff and increase community use of water for different purposes include handwashing. # Build the capacity of the WASH committees managing the solarizedse water sources by providing necessary tools and training them on both technical skill and financial management. This action will be led by the ministry of water department of scheme management. As we mobilize for the two sources an additional two boreholes within the sameareas will also be invited for the training. These will help to maximize use of expert time, cover nearby villages with capacity building plan and increase value for money by targeting more with same budget. # Support Somaliland Ministry of Water Development to ministry of water to finalize the design and construction for WASH facilities to be shared with all WASH Cluster members in Somaliland. The national WASH cluster has prioritized this action as per the request from ministry and Oxfam will contribute for this action. The budget will be used to cover some of the consultancy fees or provide expertise to help them finalize the work. # Provide safeprogramming training for WaSH committees, district administrations, women groups other key stakeholders including traditional leaders . # Protection awareness raising including community discussions on protection impact to address stigma and promotion of the call centre hotline (already operational) to increase access to covid19 services for affected communities . # Government capacity building/strengthen social safety net system in Somaliland : we will build the capacity of the government to be able to lead and coordinate Somaliland safety net program. Somalia launched safety net project called bahnano at Mogadishu but this has not been cascaded to Somaliland and Puntland. The government staff responsible for this are unable to run safety net due to their limited capacity. The project will target technical staff from the government and create enabling environment in the form of institutional capacity building including training of key staff, support implementation of beneficiaries selection and running coordination mechanisms smoothly. Oxfam Somalia is implementing social safety net activity under GFFO top up. Under this activity the project aims improving supports to HHs in urban areas particularly COVID19 affected poorest or most vulnerable to prevent them to fall to poverty and destitution trap, manage COVID19 economic and social shocks and advance their lives <(>&<)> livelihoods. The government capacity in Somaliland on social safety net is to grow and as part of appeal fund, Oxfam will contribute to strengthening/establishing social protection system that leads COVID19 response project. Oxfam will partner with Somaliland Ministry of Employment, Social and Family as socialprotection responsible government body. Somaliland government capacity is yet to grow and this project will address this gap while also coordinating with other implementing agencies to strengthen their capacity to be able to lead social assistance and provide at scale in the future to its society as a right. The project creates an opportunity for governments to become the standard responders to large scale crises.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

title.narrative: WASH support for Home quarantined HHs

description.narrative: Youth Empowerment Centre (YEC) is a not-for-profit, non-governmental, non-partisan, public and voluntary center, which was founded to work in Gaza strip. Oxfam has been working with YEC since 2010 in implementing different WASH projects including; improving public health conditions, supporting vulnerable people in urban areas and linking humanitarian approaches with sustainable resilience in the Gaza Strip. This project is built on several similar interventions implemented by Oxfam, YEC and WASH cluster members during thelast three years, as the proposed activities will cover the identified need of vulnerable families in the eastern area of Gaza governorate who did not benefit from the previous project. Oxfam will work with YEC to ensure access to systems, procedures and standards are in place to achieve effective, high quality delivery. YEC will closely coordinate with MoSD and the community committees to distribute the first hygiene kits along with the water jerrycans and Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs) to targeted families immediately after being home quarantined considering the updated COVID-19 pandemic curve. The HKs will be distributed door to door in-kind distribution considering YEC’s pre-signed agreement with relevant local suppliers for emergency response. YEC will carry out post distribution monitoring after the distribution of the 1st HKs to measure targeted beneficiaries' satisfaction and to consider their feedback and recommendations for the 2nd HKs. YEC will carry out an awareness raising campaign for the targeted HHs at Gaza North and Gaza governorate s. The proposed awareness campaign will target the 800 home quarantined families on COVID-19 protective measures such as regular handwashing, maintaining safe distance and disinfection practices considering age and gender. Specific messages will be developed to target home quarantined people and their caregivers. Awareness on relevant hygiene practices will be delivered by YECpromoters under the direct supervision of Oxfam’s Public Health officer in coordination with the HPWG and WHO/MoH recommendations.

participating-org.narrative: The YEC was established according to the Ministry of interior license number (8050) in the year 2008 as a youth initiative to meet the community requirements, the YEC was founded to lead children, adolescents, and youth to discover their purpose throughsocial, emotional, mental and physical development opportunities, while promoting positive change in the community.

LeSol's vision is to inspire society and to expand their solidarity model which promotes equality, justice, trust, respect for each other, environmental protection, creativity, empowerment and active participation.

UYONET is one of Uganda’s leading non-profit organisations for youth, acting as an umbrella organisation for youth groups across the country. Founded in 2003, UYONET is a collective platform for research, training and policy advocacy for young people, byyoung people.
The backyard farming for sustainable youth livelihood project is a 6 month project that is being implemented by Oxfam in Partnership with the Uganda Youth Network (UYONET). This project is part of the Covid response contributing directlyto the Irish Aid PG2project. UYONET will work closely with Network for Active Citizens in Westnile to mobilize youth, form groups train them to establish Back yard gardens.

participating-org.narrative:
Uganda Youth Network is a national, non-partisan and non-profit Civil Society Organization registered in Uganda as a non-governmental organization. UYONET was founded in 2002 initially as a Youth Analysis Board (YAB) and later registered as an independent national youth initiative with the overall mission to redefine the role and contribution of the Ugandan youth in the governance and development processes in the country. It was conceived by a group of young people, then student leaders in Uganda publicUniversities, who during the formative days of reintroduced plural politics in Uganda were concerned about the status of the country#s governance and leadership. They were convinced that reforming the Ugandan state required young and vibrant leadership. This necessitated the organized involvement of young people in Uganda#s democratic processes. Towards this end, following the formation of UYONET, structured dialogue among young people from the different sectors in Uganda on how to radically redefine therole of young people in political, economic and social discourses were facilitated by UYONET, starting with the formation of a loose coalition of young people called the Youth Analysis Board (YAB) that eventually transformed into UYONET as a legally registered entity.
UYONET has increasingly been demanding for a collective platform for research, training and policy advocacy for young people by young people with a vision of an Empowered youth population participating in governance and development processes. Our core mission and every day work is mainly building, empowering and sustaining a vibrant youth network through advocacy, raising awareness on sexual and reproductive health rights for young people, coordination and capacity building. We work with 37 network members all over Uganda and 157 youth organisations. Uganda Youth Network is a governance based organization and therefore strives to exhibit tenets of good corporate governance. We continue to be the premier youth organization working to enhance the contribution of youth in the governance and development processes.
The organization has a well-defined decision making structure as explained as; The Annual General Meeting (AGM); this is the organization#s highest decision making organ. Itisconstituted of all the registered and fully subscribed member organizations. Its key roles include among other; to constitute the Board, to review and approve the decisions made at different levels of decision making, review reports from the board on theimplementation of the General Assembly Decision and to approve audited books of account. The Boardis the second organ in hierarchy of decision making at UYONET. The board#s key roles include; implement the decisions of the General Assembly, support in policy formulation, policy review and implementation, constitute board sub committees to handle different management roles, receive and review secretariat decision, ensure effective management of the secretariat among others.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam Novib has been active in the Occupied Palestinian Territory/Israel (OPT/I) since 1982 and working with Palestinian refugees in Lebanon since the mid 1980s. It has built up a strong network of relationships with local NGOs and counts among its localcounterparts some of the largest and most professional NGOs in various sectors. It has accompanied these NGOs in their development from ad hoc volunteer groups to sizeable professional institutions with national outreach. At the same time the conceptualisation of the programme has evolved from three country programs in the early 1990s to a program for Palestinians in the Middle East (PME) working withPalestinians in OPT, Israel and Lebanon.
The programme has changed over the years with the establishment of the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the mid-1990s from a focus on support and service provision at a grassroots level and grassroots mobilization, to working towards influencing the establishment of the PA, its lawmaking and supporting building a democratic state # this involved supporting efforts of Palestinian civil society to build the basis for a democratic Palestinian state with room for civil participation, ensuring inclusion of vulnerable groups, refugees and women, and shaping its laws and systems. Oxfam Novib has also supported partners that are working on the provision of humanitarian assistance, response preparedness and conflict transformation. We have also supported partners in the provision of health services, access to quality education and gender justice.

Oxfam will put in place a 4-month multi-sectoral emergency response (Food, NFI, Protection and Safeguarding) to support affected households in Niger and will align itself with the government's national strategy based on the Global Response Plan to provide adequate assistance to those affected. The overall objective is to meet the immediate needs of the flood-affected populations and to help strengthen their short-term resilience.This intervention will be carried out through three main activities:1. 1. Support for unconditional multi-sectoral cash transfer: The option for an unconditional cash transfer aims to allow each beneficiary to decide, in full responsibility, what to do with the money received, taking into account the diversity of needs. In addition, a summary analysis madeby the World Food Programme at the national level shows that this modality is appropriate for the Zinder region. Thus, nearly 500 vulnerable affected households will benefit from this activity. 2. Protection monitoringThis monitoring aims to ensure the protection of vulnerable groups (women, people living with a disability, deminus) against all forms of abuse and the respect of their universal rights through monitoring of protection and referral of any cases identified to appropriate care structures. A network of community relays will be set up under the supervision of a MobCom for this monitoring. These people will be prioritized in the targeting inorder to ensure that they are taken into account in the distribution. 3. MasssensitizationThese sensitizations will be conducted inthe villages, during distributions and if necessary through spots in community radios. They will deal mainly with the risks relatedto waterborne diseases such as cholera and sanitation. If need be, themes related to abuse will be addressed for prevention and to raise awareness of these populations on the means of recourse. These sensitizations will be carried out in compliance with the measures to fight against Covid 19 enacted by the State of Niger. Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version)

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novibs main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fund raising, campaigning and advocacy. The Hub Niamey Niger exists since 2006 as a humanitarian field office and since 2012 as the decentralized Country office for Oxfam Novib, dealing with all the development and humanitarian themes like Sustainable livelihoods, Right to Basic services, Humanitarian and resilience interventions, The right to be heard and the right to an Identity, including women's rights and sexual and reproductive health rights. The Country Office in Niger works with local partners to realize the vision of a Niger without poverty

The areas targeted under this project already had protection concerns and that has significantly increased in the COVID-19 pandemicsituation and associated lockdown. Oxfam and OWH proposes a structured and timely response to the increased protection needs of IDPs, returnees and host communities in Herat and Helmand provinces of Afghanistan. Oxfam aims to assist 38,320 individuals (15,328 women, 11,496 men, 7664 girls and 3832 boys) who are severely affected by conflicts, flood, drought and Covid-19, by providing protection and Gender Based Violence (GBV) services which include a multisector response (legal, safety, health and psychosocial) through door-to door outreach and referrals that facilitate community based specialized services. Women and girls’ survivors are provided withdignity kits in Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), information dissemination through media broadcasts on women rights to increaseawareness, GBV and case management, referral and follow up of protection cases. Oxfam will adopt an integrated approach, leveragingprotection activities aligned with the priorities laid out in the AHF 5th Reserve Allocation-2020 with the eventual objective of recovery and resilience-building in the target communities. Provision of immediate protection assistance will alleviate suffering of beneficiaries in a gender sensitive manner and increase their resilience. The protection activities based on identified needs on the ground will be implemented in Hirat Province: (Kush e Robat Sangi , Zinda Jan,Adrakshan <(>&<)> Ghoryan) and Helmand Province: (Nad Ali, Grishk, Lashkar Gah and Nawe Barakzai) The main objectives of the project are to: save lives, alleviate suffering and protect human dignity for the most vulnerable, support people to build their resilience and increase capacity on human rights and women’s rights to reduce protection violations, are reduced and respect for international humanitarian law(IHL) is increased through protectionservices. Oxfam’s protection program provides practical protection support, through Women Friendly Health Spaces (WFHS), psychosocial, legal services, referral of beneficiaries with protection concerns to other service providers, door to door mobile outreach and community based right information dissemination. Oxfam <(>&<)>OHW has achieved concrete successes in environments such as Herat and Helmand provinces and has an established presence in these provinces while to build on this work, Oxfam will use the AHF 5th Reserved Allocation-2020-21 funding to increase the scope andscale of its protection activities, and to conduct broaden right awareness through media broadcasting in TV/radio programming to a wider population. AHF 5th RA 2020-21’s contribution to this project will support returnees, displaced and host communities to undertake protection services ( Psychosocial/Legal, referrals <(>&<)> follow up of protection cases, community right awareness raising, mobile outreach and train community based protection committees (CBPC) for sustainability of the project. Oxfam <(>&<)> OWH willprovide training and sensitization on International Humanitarian law (IHL) and protection to a majority of individuals in the affected communities whom are unaware of the available referral systems and GBV mitigation strategies in order to increase awareness on GBV risks, available referral pathways and mitigation strategies. Oxfam and OHW will establish 4 women friendly health spaces, community dialogues and mobile community outreach which will support protection responses inwider communities.

participating-org.narrative: Organization of Human Welfare (OHW) was, established in 2007 by former Oxfam management following Oxfam GBs strategic withdrawal from direct implementation in the southern region. The organization is focused on supporting and enabling the most vulnerablecommunities, those who have little or no access to basic services, such as health, nutrition, education, and water and sanitation and vulnerable livelihoods, in their quest toward economic development, prosperity and sustainability. Vision: Improved wellbeing and poverty reduction for poor, vulnerable and marginalized people. Mission: The primary objective of the organization is to improve the well-being of poor and vulnerable people by creating, providing and promoting opportunities to improve their livelihoods and access to basicservices, and to assure their fundamental rights irrespective of race, ethnicity, gender, religion or political belief

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam works to help poor and marginalized people to gain control over their own lives by exercising their right to political participation, freedom of expression and information, freedom of assembly, and access to justice. Many projects currently being executed by Oxfam in Afghanistan on women and youth fall under this campaign.
In Afghanistan, ON has been working with local NGOs, civil society organisations and networks through a number of initiatives to raise awareness about human rights, promote women's participation and leadership, and empower citizens to speak out on issues that affect their lives and to improve governance

The project will provide emergency response to the most vulnerable households (HHs) in Nangarhar who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and were already struggling to manage their minimum essential food needs, it is worsened by the loss of income/earning opportunity and thus purchasing power, as a result of COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan. The beneficiaries of this project are also living in recently cleared districts that are facing degraded food security situation due to long exposure to conflict. The most vulnerable people are included, specifically female headed HH, and HH with PWD and or where the primary breadwinner haslost their employment due to COVID-19. Through the proposed project Oxfam and long-term strategic partner Organization for Human Welfare (OHW) will provide cash assistance to a total of 15,000 individuals (2143 HHs) in Achin and Mohmandara districts of Nangarhar province to buy food items/commodities - these districts were recently cleared by Afghan National Forces from existence of ISIS. Based on the cluster standards and the allocation strategy paper, every eligible beneficiary HHs (those who experienced multiple resilience eroding shock in the past 6 months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressures, including lack of employment). they will receive half basket cash for food for 2 months (USD 90 for a period of 2 months in local currency) in one off. Cash for Food was preferred by the majority of the persons interviewed during the needs assessment since the local markets are operational. The Market Assessment confirmed that access is available and there is no restriction for both male and female while accessing/approaching market. The assessment revealed that, 40% of respondents identified cash, 18% preferred food, 6% education, 6% shelter, 25% WASH, and the rest of the 5% health facilities as first priorities. Similarly, 15% identified food, 27% cash, 25% preferred education, 11% preferred health facilities, 4% preferred shelter, and the rest 5% preferred WASH as second priorities. Oxfam’s interventions will be guided by the Integrated Food-Security Phase Classification (IPC) and Seasonal Food Security Assessment (SFSA) findings. As per IPC 2020 andSFSA, Nangarhar province was already in Crisis Situation (IPC3). Around 46% of the population in Nangarhar (1,237,262 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the period of April-May 2020 and 40% of the population (559,938 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the projection period June to November 2020. This project will support the most food-insecure population/communities in rural areas of Nangarhar Province, Achin and Mohmandara districts. FSAC identified that communities affected by COVID-19 are among the worst hit in terms of food insecurity. This project will target them so that they can survive without adopting harmful coping strategies and reduce their risk of exposure to the further shocks and build their resilience. A beneficiary selection committee using a weighted vulnerability score will be set up and also mention that post distribution monitoring (PDM) will be conducted and will include questions related to risks associated with cash distribution and efforts made to facilitate inclusive, safe and secure access of all beneficiaries (women, children, PWD, elderly) to cash assistance. COVID-19 Awareness raising messages developed by Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) with the support of World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF in the languages of Afghanistan will be used for this purpose. Oxfam will integrate conflict sensitivity into the action, by conducting context and conflict analysis of the target areas. This is especially important as cash assistance can work as potential flashpoint in creatingnew conflict or exacerbating existing tensions. The grant of USD 300,000 will provide immediate response and save lives of 15,000 persons (USD 20 per person).

Reducing Inequalities for Women and Youth for Active Citizenship The present project entitled: Reducing Inequalities towards Women and Youth for Active Citizenship was identified after analysis of the unfortunate events that occurred in the city of Niamey and Zinder among others :- In 2011, the student demonstration that resulted in the death of a student and a woman and enormous damage to public and private property in the city of Zinder ;- The demonstration of January 14, 2014 of students of the College of General Education 4 and College of Secondary Education Barma Mustapha of Zinder, which resulted in breakages at the regional police headquarters,on public and private property (three vehicles ransacked and burned, offices vandalized ....);- In Niamey, the march of schoolchildren caused many break-ins in November 2013;- On April 10, 2017, death of the student Bagalé Mallah following the confrontation between the Defense and Security Forces and the students of Abdoul Moumouni University in Niamey; - Strong protest reactions following the march "I am Charlie" in 2015, in almost all major cities of Niger but in Niamey and Zinder the march was more violent: burned churches, houses and state buildings ransacked, theft of property of others, deaths of menand arrest of demonstrators. - In 2020, with the measures taken by the government as part of the prevention of COVID, young people in Niamey, particularly the Goudel district and Cité Député, organized protests against these measures, particularly the curfew introduced and the ban on places of worship, including Friday prayers. Demonstrations were violent, and there was extensive damage to property, which led the government to arrest thedemonstrators/demonstrators. It is important to note, with political tensions, high unemployment and unemployed youth, poverty, and lack of a culture of citizenship, whenever students are on strike, the movement is sometimes recuperated by political structures and organizations and infiltrated by people outside the law.Thus, instead of marching peacefully with a well-traced route no, the streets are transformed into battlefields and both public and private property destroyed. The demonstration is a right for every citizen because it is provided for in the constitution,but the protection and respect of public and private property is also a duty for every citizen. These acts of vandalism are surely due to the lack of knowledge and/or the non-respect of the rights and duties of citizenship, which boils down to a lack oftheculture of citizenship among young people. Thus to make its modest contribution, the NGO Nagari has in partnership with the NGO EIRENE works with the Fadas of young people of Goudel on a project entitled: Promotion of peacein peri-urban areas of Niamey.So the main activities are :- Information and sensitization sessions for the youth of the Fadas in order to strengthen peaceful cohabitation; - Concertations and dialogue with youth groups on conflict prevention and management mechanisms,- Training of young leaders on non-violent conflict management.- Production of radio programs with the Youth of the Fadas.- Creation of a whatsapp group and production and exchange of small messagesTo strengthen/complete this initiative and broaden its scope of intervention, the NGO Nagari approached the communal authorities of the commune 1 of Niamey and Zinder for this innovative project. Through a game on the basis of the tool Democra pol, the project will allow to reinforce the culture of the citizen, and a betterknowledge of human rights and the role and responsibilities of the actors of decentralization and in the management/control of infrastructures. This initiative is particularly aimed at the involvement of young people (school children and members of Fadas/club) indecision-making spheres and their accountability in the management of their respective entities and even of the entire country.Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version)

participating-org.narrative: Action pour la Promotion de la Paix la Bonne Gouvernance et le Développ

The NGO Action for the Promotion of Peace, Good Governance and Development APBGD-NAGARI is an apolitical national association created and registered in Niger under the number 268 / MISPD / ACR / DGAPJ / DLP of April 13, 2015. NAGARI is created by 11 former staffsof the German developpement cooperation through its peacekeeping program. NAGARI ONG is established in Niger and is active in the regions of Dosso, Niamey and Tillabéry. NAGARI aims to contribute to the promotion of peace and reinforcement of social cohesion between different social groups. NAGARI is an active member of the big national coalition on Non violent conflict management named GENOVICO.

In October 2020, torrential rain caused by a tropical convergence zone combined with cold air mass (05 Oct), tropical storms no. 6 Linfa and no. 7 Nangka, additional tropical depression resulted in severe floods in all the 16 main river systems in the Central coastal area of Vietnam. Following the tropical storm no. 8 Saudel, super typhoon Molave (storm no. 9) caused more heavy rain on the provinces already devastated by weeks of intense multi-disasters. As a consequence, more than 7 million people in Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Thua Thien Hue, Da Nang, Quang Nam, Quang Ngai provinces were seriously affected.
In flood affected areas in Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, and Quang Nam provinces, the most in-need groups are those with pre-existing vulnerabilities before floods happened. HCCD’s needs assessment on 24-25 Oct indicated that people are in critical shortage of rice, and nutritional food, access to safe drinking water, and women and girls need dignity hygiene items in short term, and appropriate support to assist them in early recovery phase (WASH, livelihood recovery, risks communication). Cash relief has been repeatedly recommended as local markets restored to normal in most of affected areas.
The project "Central Vietnam Flooding Emergency" is implemented by Oxfam, in collaboration with the Ha Tinh Center for Community Development (HCCD) and Quang Nam Red Cross in 4 provinces: Quảng Trị, Quảng Bình, Hà Tĩnh, and Quảng Nam. The implementation period is from November 2020 to May 2021.
Oxfam will work through its locally-established implementing partners HCCD, IWEM, CIRD, and Vietnam Red Cross to timely respond to priority life-saving and recovery needs through Multi-Purpose Cash Assistance, delivery of dignity hygiene kits, and water buckets to some 25,000 women, men, and children of 6,200 hardest hit households in 3 provinces. They will be accompanied by WASH-Covid promotion campaigns to enhance local-readiness and response capacityto water related health risks.
Early recovery support will mainly focus on livelihood support interventions, including an in-depth livelihood/ market assessment, cash for work activities for integrated WASH-FSL recovery for vulnerable smallholders suffering from damaged arable land and livestock and theongoing economic devastation caused by Covid. Recovery support will include installation water tanks to targeted beneficiaries including women headed household and most disadvantaged people, plus continuation of community-led WASH-Covid risk communications. Based on needs assessment and in coordination with Plan and World Vision, the selected districts are: Cam Xuyen, Thach Ha (in Ha Tinh), Tuyen Hoa (in Quang Binh) and Bac Tra My (in Quang Nam) which were heavily affected by prolonged floods, landslidesand typhoon Molave .
We will mitigate risks to livelihoods by providing choices for income generation for disaster affected men and women, the elderly people, and people with disabilities to participate in cash for work schemes to repair public work andbasic infrastructure. Awareness raising campaigns include key messages on water safe storage, hygiene behaviour, public health risk reduction measures, Covid prevention, will be disseminated in person and through radio. Working with the UN Agencies such as Unicef, WHO, and FAO, and Ministry of Health, Ministry of Agriculture will ensure coordination efforts with relevant ministries/agencies.
EFSVL-WASH, and MPCA activities are adapted to Oxfam’s guidelines on community-facing activities during COVID19, cash transfer considering gender dynamics and protection; beneficiary registration, KIIs, cash for work activities and distributions willfollow distancing rules.
Ha Tinh Centre for Community Development (HCCD) will lead the local response operation,and will collaborate with district and commune Red Cross and Women Union, and commune People’s Committees, for quality and accountable delivery of the response package. It is estimated that HCCD and local humanitarian actors will take up to 70% of thelocal implementation and management of the response on the ground.

participating-org.narrative: Ha Tinh Center For Community Develo

Ha Tinh Centre for Community Development (HCCD) is a local Vietnamese non-governmental and non-profit organization. Its mission focuses only on poverty reduction and community development. Ha Tinh Centre for Community Development (HCCD) has been established at a Decision No. 42/QD-UB dated on 29th March, 2004 issued by Ha Tinh Provincial People#s Committee.
HCCD believes in its right-based approach, to ensure that the rights of people living in poverty, disadvantaged people, and vulnerable groups arerespected and materialized. The above-mentioned target groups should be aware of, listened to, and provided with opportunities to participate and are keyagents of planning and decision making processes. HCCD values active involvement of relevant stakeholders through collaborating with government bodies, partners at different levels, and core groups in community development in implementation process of programs and projects in community development and emergency response areas.

The equality in action program (Volunteer Cooperation program) is a global capacity building program for local partner organizations delivered mainly through Canadian volunteers and other mechanisms. The program aims to increase the social and economic well beingof the poorest, most marginalized people, especially women and girls. This should be achieved by increasing partners' performance from 13 countries in implementing more inclusive, innovative and sustainable development initiatives that advance gender equalityand inclusive governance. Additionally, the program will increase canadians' participation in international development and key global issues by supporting gender equality, empowerment of women and girls, and inclusive governance through working closely with partners and supporting their needs and capacities.Through this program, TAM in Bethlehem will implement a peer learning initiative to explore and highlight women's leadership and entrepreneurial role during the Covid-19 pandemic.TAM will focus on women who have been creative during the pandemic and form new ways to manage their lives, families and livelihood. The main aim of this initiative is toempower Palestinian Women through positive models during the Covid-19 Pandemic. The action will include learning exchanges on women's positive and sustainable initiatives. Short films will be produced and disseminated to highlight and share the positive influencewomen could make in society.

participating-org.narrative: Women Media and Development- TAM, is a Palestinian non- governmental organization. TAM mission is to seek Society in which women are able to communicate and advocate for their rights in order to achieve their goals and aspirations. TAM considers media asan effective and a key instrument to achieve community development, gender equality and women empowerment. Under this project, TAM will workon building the capacity of targeted group in West Bank on digital security issues to reduce cyber GBV (prevention, protection and mitigation strategies) and to increase women political participation and leadership. Building on this TAM will work on carrying outcommunity engagement and awareness raising to young women and men gender advocates and cyber activists in West Bank on the safe use of ICT to enhance young women's political participation and leadership. Besides, TAM will work to empower targeted groups to exertinfluence on duty bearers and community leaders to decrease GBV and increase women political participation and leadership. This will be realized through carrying out policy dialogue workshops with targeted Palestinian marginalized groups in West Bank on digital laws and legislation affecting Palestinians. The results of this intervention will bemanifested in carrying out an advocacy campaignin West Bank and Gaza to call for legal and policy amendments that will promote Palestinian women's rights related to gender justice and digitization. TAM will contribute to carry out and Online awareness raising campaign led by Taghyeer on the Palestinian Electronic crimes law and the Israeli cyber security and national cyber Directorate Bill to capacitate users on safe ways o use social media, raise awareness about services available to survivors of cyberviolence and critically review cyber laws. Finally, TAM will be Supporting counseling and/or referral services and ensures its accessibility and availability to survivors of cyber violence, working on providing direct support, counseling and referral to survivors of cyber violence.

participating-org.narrative: The Womens Affairs Centre in Gaza focuses on research and training to promote the equal rights of women in Palestinian society. Itsgoal is to empower women politically, economically and socially and to promote gender awareness in Palestinian society. WAC does this through a program of research, training and lobby to overcome obstacles to the equality of men and women, to analyse and develop tools and strategies for overcoming them. WAC is also involved in activities such as training women to set up and improve small enterprises, in how to use cameras for making videos and films, and in writing and computer skills. The research program is linked to its activities on the themes of child marriages, violence against women and womens rights. WAC has been working in Gaza since 1991 andOxfam Novib has been supporting it since 1992.

Water is life: building thriving communities in rural niger Niger is the lowest ranking county on the human development index and suffers from chronic poverty, extreme weather conditions, such as drought, and the long-term impact of conflict. Only onein two people living in rural Niger have access to safe drinking water. This is largely due to the severe lack of adequate water infrastructureto support the population’s needs. This is because the government focuses on funding urban rather than rural areas. Any infrastructure that does exist has a low level of functionality (13.85% in Tillabéry and 8.09% in Zinder). This is largely due to the low capacity of local technical services to repair and optimize existing water points due to a lack of fundingand knowledge. The limited number of repair men that are available to service the water points face shortages of the spare parts necessary for pump maintenance. This is due to less investment in the poorest, most marginalised areas, and on-going issues with the spare parts supply chain. This lack of water and sanitation facilities has a knock-on effect on people’s health, education and livelihoods. In rural Niger: • Women and girls walk daily, up to 8kms, to access water from traditional water sources, and rivers that do not meet acceptable standards for drinking water.
• Child mortality (under 5s) stands at 8.4%, twenty times higher than the UK, and this is partially due to preventable, diarrhoeal diseases spread through a lack of awareness of good hygiene practices and no access to clean water.
• Open air defection and a lack of best practice regarding handwashing, for example using soap, are commonplace, leading to the spread of disease such as COVID-19 .
• 75% of the rural population has not attended school or received any level of education, partially due to theburden of domestic responsibilities such as collecting water which tends to be located far from households
• Men are often absent,as they travel to other regions to find work, leaving women-headed households that rely on market gardening for food for their family and to sell at the local market. Without access to water they cannot grow crops critical to their nutrition and their ability to make an income.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novibs main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fund raising, campaigning and advocacy. The Hub Niamey Niger exists since 2006 as a humanitarian field office and since 2012 as the decentralized Country office for Oxfam Novib, dealing with all the development and humanitarian themes like Sustainable livelihoods, Right to Basic services, Humanitarian and resilience interventions, The right to be heard and the right to an Identity, including women's rights and sexual and reproductive health rights. The Country Office in Niger works with local partners to realize the vision of a Niger without poverty

participating-org.narrative: DEMI-E is a Nigerien NGO recognized by decree N°405/MI/AT/DAPJ/SA of October 28, 1998. Its head office is located in Zinder with representations in the regions of Diffa, Tillabéry, Tahoua, Maradi and Niamey. Its governance is structured around three mainbodies namely the General Assembly (GA) which is the supreme body of the organization, the Board of Directors (BOD) which is the management body of DEMI-E and the Executive Secretariat which is the executive body of DEMI-E as summarized in the following organization chart:The organizational model defined by the NGO responds to the following issues: - How to reach a maximum of beneficiaries? - How to improve the impact and effectiveness of interventions?- How to optimize the geographical coverage of the NGO?Our vision: ''DEMI-E aspires to a world where everyone participates voluntarily, equitably and inclusively in the sustainable well-being of communities''.Ourmission: DEMI-E's mission is to ''Contribute to the strengthening of the resilience capacitiesof rural and urban communities through the implementation of self-managed development initiatives''. Our intervention strategy : DEMI-E's intervention strategy is based on its strategic planning, internal policies and procedures and takes into account national development orientations (3N Initiative,PDES, etc.). It is essentially based on the needs of the populations. The NGO DEMI-E wants to listen to the Nigerien population, through the needs expressed by the villages, communes, associations and groups. It wants to be proactive by proposing initiatives, by defining projects jointly with the service seekers. The NGO DEMI-E develops itself taking into account the socio-economic environment of Niger, it adapts to the constraints of the environment, structural changes, technological evolution, new communication systems.Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version)

Revenue collection is important for national development of Cambodia and sustaining Cambodia's economic growths. Many reforms in public financial management for past years have yielded significant result. Not until the occurrence of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Royal Government has injected billions of dollars from the national reserves and national budget through the Covid-19 intervention measures. Cambodia's economy is projected to decrease to around 2 percent of total GDP growth for the year 2020. The Government intervention measure of Covid-19 has greatly touched on the delay of paying taxes and tax declaration for any affected sectors and yield greater losses on government revenue. Such phenomena requires stronger scrutiny from the public and civil society organization over fiscal accountability both revenue and expenditure of national budget.
However, despite the progress in terms of revenue collection and taxation and increases of public expenditures, according to Open Budget Survey in 2019, the role of citizen in the budget process remains limited throughout the whole budget process ranging from budget proposal, implementation of the budget plan, and the evaluation of the budget. Several reasons that can explain this problem is firstly the lack of platform where citizen can participate in the process, especially at a national level. Second, the nature of budget process is highly technical that it requires participants topossess a certain extent of knowledge in order to be able to participate meaningfully.
Therefore, TI Cambodia’s strategy focuses mainly on the role of youth in participating in budget process at both national and sub-national level. The initiative named “Young Budget Trackers” is created to bring together young and potential youth to contribute in policy research and advocacy on open budget, taxation, and pro-poor and FAIR tax and trade policy to the Royal Government of Cambodia to promote fiscal accountability and transparency. Well-equipped and qualified youth will be ableto use evident based research as an advocacy to policy makers and stakeholders involved.
More open space for citizen and youth to actively engage in fiscal accountability through evident based advocacy on open budget, taxation, pro-poor and FAIR tax and trade policy at national and sub-national levels. OUTCOME: Broader youth participation in fiscal accountability
OUTPUT 1: Youth’ knowledge and capacity on national and sub national budget process, taxation, pro-poor and FAIR tax and trade policy enhanced
OUTPUT 2: Youth’s participation and advocacy for fiscal accountability through evident basedadvocacy at national and sub-national levels empowered

participating-org.narrative: Transparency International Cambodia (TI Cambodia) is a fully-accredited National Chapter of Transparency International. Our missionis to work together with individuals and institutions at all levels to promote integrity and reduce corruption in Cambodia. Transparency International Cambodia (TIC) is a chapter of Transparency International which was established in 2010. Its mission is working to fight corruption, and promote integrity, transparency, and accountability in Cambodia. Oxfam in Cambodia has been in partnership with TIC in 2016 under Finance for Development project. The initiative named “Young Budget Trackers” is created to bring together young and potential youth to contribute to policy research and advocacy on open budget, taxation, and pro-poor and FAIR tax and trade policy to the Royal Government of Cambodia to promote fiscal accountability and transparency. The initiative is proposed in line with the current strategic plan of TI Cambodia to engage and empower citizen and youth. It reflects TI Cambodia’s goal to strengthen the capacity of citizens and especially youth that serve to bring their interest around a common cause that matters to them such as fiscal accountability and transparency. Overall Objective: More open space for citizen and youth to actively engage in fiscal accountability through evident based advocacy on open budget, taxation, pro-poor and FAIR tax and trade policy at national and sub-national levels.

Oxfam will implement in partnership of ESDC a project that supports vulnerable affected farmers herdersa dn small scale businesses to recover from COVID 19 crisis. The project will be implemented in the Area C of the West bank and will target women, farmers and herders and youth. Oxfam will carry out several communication activities that aim at raising awareness on the COVID-19 precautionary measures. The project will also include piloting community based protection activity and will Implement community-led lobby activities with relevant stakeholders to raise their awareness on barriers in access to protection and emergency services, with recommendations to consider these barriers while designing and delivering services.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam Novib has been active in the Occupied Palestinian Territory/Israel (OPT/I) since 1982 and working with Palestinian refugees in Lebanon since the mid 1980s. It has built up a strong network of relationships with local NGOs and counts among its localcounterparts some of the largest and most professional NGOs in various sectors. It has accompanied these NGOs in their development from ad hoc volunteer groups to sizeable professional institutions with national outreach. At the same time the conceptualisation of the programme has evolved from three country programs in the early 1990s to a program for Palestinians in the Middle East (PME) working withPalestinians in OPT, Israel and Lebanon.
The programme has changed over the years with the establishment of the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the mid-1990s from a focus on support and service provision at a grassroots level and grassroots mobilization, to working towards influencing the establishment of the PA, its lawmaking and supporting building a democratic state # this involved supporting efforts of Palestinian civil society to build the basis for a democratic Palestinian state with room for civil participation, ensuring inclusion of vulnerable groups, refugees and women, and shaping its laws and systems. Oxfam Novib has also supported partners that are working on the provision of humanitarian assistance, response preparedness and conflict transformation. We have also supported partners in the provision of health services, access to quality education and gender justice.
