title.narrative: CO-Response To Cyclone Crisis in Somali

description.narrative: The program will be achieved through focusing on unconditional cash transfer transfers targeting the most vulnerable IDPs and host communities affected by COVID 19 economically and exacerbated by GATI cyclone, based on the food consumption scoring and loss of livelihood assets. This intervention forms approximately 70% of the total cash transfer programming under Oxfam’s overall response and will be implemented directly by Oxfam by engaging electronic financial service provider in Puntland via mobile phones. Beneficiarieswho don’t possess Sim-cards will receive them as part of this response and be trained on its usage. The overall Oxfam food securityintervention which this contributes towards will include additional emergency livelihoods and recovery elements including cash for work interventions to rebuild destroyed feeder roads.Oxfam targets households that meet the critical food insecurity criteria takingintoconsideration gender-differentiated needs. The selection criteria will be discussed with thetarget women, men, boys and girls toensure fairness of the selection process. Usually, women are registered as beneficiaries and the head of the household for cash transfers. At times we find that some polygamous households are includedduring registration stage and this is addressed during verification, ensuring that the most vulnerable HH are Commented [AC12]: In addition to these activities DEC funds can also be used to coverany hygiene promotion activities/hygiene kits, COVID messaging, PPE for staffif needed?Commented [MH13R12]: We Have some PPE in thefield, Moses to add purchase of some PPE in the budget targeted, in collaboration with community leaders. Female-headed households are the most affected as they do not have access to meaningful household assets such as livestock, or other sources of income. In Bari region, priorities for livelihood regeneration activities are different for women and men. Oxfam will deliver emergency food security interventions through cash grants for the most vulnerable people, while supporting household income by strengtheningand diversifying livelihoods through other projects. Oxfam's programming since March 2017 has successfully diversified the source of livelihoods in traditional pastoralist communities in Somaliland with plansto replicate this expereicnce in Puntland. This intervention will help vulnerable households to have some disposable income which they can use to purchase or meet their household food needs.Most vulnerable community members that will be most in need of the emergency assistance through this action will be identified through participatory mapping exercises conducted at village level through specific exercises including well-being rankings, vulnerability mapping, food consumption score, household purchasing power, among others. Gender will be consideredwhen selecting households to help reduce the additional burden on women headedhouseholds. The criteria shall be clearly explained to the selection committee/panel prior toselection, with clearcommunication on what beneficiaries will be entitled to during the project, to avoid unrealistic expectations.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

Reconnect Health Development Initiative (RHDI) is a not-for-profit, non-government organization headquartered in Nigeria for 6 years to promote awareness of mental health issues, and provide psychological treatment and support services for individuals, groups andcommunities. Working together with relevant stakeholders, we affirm our commitment to support and alleviate the sufferings of persons affected by gender-based violence, disasters, crises, violence, mental health disorders, psychological and substance abuse problems. We believe no one should face a mental health problem alone and we would not give up until everyone in need of psychological support access the support the require. This project seeks to provide an integrated support system to women and girls with the view to build their resilience to break the culture of silence while addressing social norms that promote gender based violence (GBV) in 3 states in Nigeria (FCT, Adamawa <(>&<)> Taraba State). This will be done in collaboration with relevant Government Agencies and a local Women’s Rights partner.
Project Objectives i. Provide psychological services for women and girls at risk of GBV through psychological telephone helpline and face-to-face service for 300 women and girls by December 2021 ii. Provide online mental healthcare and psychological services via social media platform and establish safe-space support groups for 900 women and girls by March 2021 in target communities in Nigeria iii. Develop persuasive health messaging for a behaviour change support system that promotes non-violence for 1, 000, 000 Nigerian women and girls under the Enough Campaign in Nigeria by March 2021 iv. Facilitate a linkage between 900 survivors of VAWG with GBV response therapy support services in Nigeria by March, 2021
With social, cultural stigma and psychological trauma as stressors that prevent women and girls from seeking help after GBV, the delivery of this 4.5 month project embraces 3 approaches

participating-org.narrative:
Reconnect Health Development Initiative (RHDI) is an mental health non-profit, non-government organization headquartered in Nigeriasince 2013, to provide psychological treatment and support services to address mental health issues while providing psychological treatment services to people and communities. Working together with relevant stakeholders, we affirm our commitment to support and alleviate the sufferings of persons affected by disasters, mental disorder, psychological and substance abuse problems. We believe no one should face a mental health challenge alone and we would not give up until everyone in need of psychological support access the required.
Reconnect HDI has nearly 50 seasoned professionals comprising of Clinical and Behavioural Psychologists, Educational and Child Psychologists, Consultant Psychiatrists, Public Health Specialists and Counsellors. With our partners from the public, privateand NGO sectors, our contribution to the psychosocial space is unparalleled
Our Objectives are: * To raise awareness and combat stigma on mental illness through culturally appropriate methods. * To care and protect the wellbeing and rights of vulnerable population including survivors of gender based violence. * To promote access and availability of psychosocial and treatment services. * To host research on mental health to inform policies and sustain wellbeing of beneficiaries. * To strengthen partnerships and platforms of support for individuals, communities and groups.

description.narrative: Since 2001, AJOAGO with support of main partners is involved in successfully preparedness and response, improving water, sanitationand hygiene services, food security and other programmes in rural communities of Mozambique. Thus far services have been installed in main districts of 5 different provinces of the country. This project targets at least 3.000 households in Guara Guara resettlement neighbourhoods in Buzi District. Through the project these people will achieve tangible improvements in their health status, welfare and dignity through increased and sustainable access to improved water and hygiene facilities delivery and by applying associatedhygiene practices to prevent COVID 19 Pandemic.

Somalia is one of the most fragile and complex humanitarian crises in the world. The country is emerging from more than three decades of conflicts with weak formal government systems since the collapse of the central governmentin the early 1990s.Decades ofarmed conflicts coupled with recurrent drought conditions, famine, persistent food insecurity, protracted population displacement as well as seasonal flooding have left the country suffering one of the world’s worst humanitarian situations. The southern Somalia has been the worst affected with the region experiencing cycles of conflict that have destroyed legitimate institutions and created widespread vulnerability. While situation was dire alreadydueto protracted conflicts and drought, COVID 19 pandemic emergence detoriorated both health and livelihood sources of Somali community. In DEC phase 2, Oxfam plans to provide an integrated WASH and food security project to support emergency food crises and support recovery of livelihoods lost due to drought or COVID 19 pandemic in Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland administrative regions of Somalia. EFSVL Component: The project will addresshumanitarian needs of the IDPs, poor urban and returnees and will support cash and voucher assistance(CVA) to people affected by triple threats of conflict, drought and COVID 19 economically. This will be complemented to supportingLivelihood restoration for women groups affected by COVID pandemic toenable them to resume or establish viable livelihood options intended to provide sustainable livelihood opportunities for affected IDPs, returnees and host community in target 11regions of Somalia. This outcome will alleviate the sufferingof 6,780 people from extreme effects of COVID 19 i mpact and improve their food security situation. WASH Outcomes: A total of 8000people are expected to benefit from rehabilitation of three strategic water points coupled by hygiene and promotion activities. COVID 19 awareness raising will be conducted for 60,000people in all target regions of the project with the aim of reducing spread of this pandemic. This outcome will benefita total of 60,000people. The project will benefita total of 60,000peopleand will be implemented in the same districts as DEC phase 1 in Puntland and Somaliland while the project target Kismayo district of Lower Juba region. Oxfam continues to work with WASDA in this project and implementationmodalitywill remain mixed approach. The activities are in line with Oxfam’s Humanitarian Strategy forSomalia and contributes to our Oxfam Coutnry Strategy (OSC)2020-2025.

participating-org.narrative: WASDA was established as a nongovernmental in Somalia in 2001. The organisation strives to supplement the efforts of governments and other development stakeholders in addressing developmental challenges in the Horn of Africa. WASDA is currently implementing development initiatives in North-Eastern Kenya and parts of Southern Somalia. WASDA has been working with pastoral communities in North-Eastern Kenya and Southern Somalia for 23 years. The organisation has, in the process, gained and built a wealth of experience and knowledge that informs its programming. It utilises limited resources to change the lives of millions of people in its geographical areas of operation. In the last 23 years, WASDA has reached over 1.5 million people with livelihood, food security; water; sanitation and hygiene; health and nutrition; education and emergency humanitarian support. VISION Empowered communities in the Horn of Africa that are resilient, innovative and peaceful MISSION To mobilize and engage communities and other stakeholders in creating strategic partnerships for sustainable management of the environment, water resources, livelihoods, and education and public health services in the Horn of Africa.

Its general goal is to support projects of rural people, women above all, in their production activities, with the goal to increase food security.

Cyclone Eloise hit Sofala province in early January, creating a trail of destruction with an epicenter in the districts of Buzi andNhamatanda. As part of its life-saving mandate, Oxfam and its local partners AJOAGO and Kulima, intend to intervene and respond to this emergency by focusing on the WASH area of supporting people accommodated in accommodation centers created to people whose homes have been completely destroyed. Specifically, the project intend to provide to the affected populations providethem services suchas water supply via water trucking. The hygiene conditions is low in the accommodation centers because of that the project intended to distribute hygiene kits and dignity kits. On the other hand, awareness lectures will be given on good hygiene practices and preventive measures against COVID-19. This intervention will last approximately 45 days. Oxfam's role will be to provide technical assistance to partners on the ground through.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education forall, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam established this country office to support local organizations and projects. Through this local office Oxfam Novib directly contributes towards this project’s implementation.

participating-org.narrative: The Afghan Development Association (ADA) was established in 1990 with the purpose of improving agricultural productivity in rural Afghanistan. Agricultural areas have suffered considerably as a result of almost 24 years of civil war in the country. Theirrigation system of canals and karezes (small water tunnels), on which large parts of agrarian land depend, were damaged or destroyed, or goneinto disuse after years of neglect. The consequences of the civil war include the displacement of large numbers of people and severe disruption of the economy and livelihoods of numerous poor families. ADA has concentrated its efforts in the southern and western regions of the country. Given the relative security and stability in these areas during Taliban rule,thedisplaced and refugee population of the region has been gradually returning from surrounding areas and countries. The drought prevailing for the last three years has, however, slowed down the repatriation process to some extent. The returning populationis in need of continued support to facilitate their re-integration. ADA has developed a multi-sectoral, integrated rural development package that includes the rehabilitation of irrigation systems, horticulture development, agricultural inputs (such as fertilisers, improved seed varieties, tools), veterinary training, health education, vocational training, and environmental conservation. Oxfam Novib has provided support to ADA for Integrated Rural Development Projects for several years entailing thefollowing aspects of development: encouraging and facilitating return of refugees; rehabilitating and developing rural infrastructure including farm activities; creating employment and livelihood opportunities; facilitating socio-economic reintegration; and ensuring the participation of local communities in the rural rehabilitation activities. Major components covered with Oxfam Novib support have included: the rehabilitation of rural infrastructure; food security; water supply; and vocational training. Theprojects have served tens of thousands of families. All these services were found useful in the direction of accomplishing broader objectives of alleviating poverty and fostering peace in Afghanistan.

2020 was one of the hardest years for Somalia in decades. Flooding, COVID-19 and recurring locust invasions heavily impacted on theeconomy and livelihoods of people. The government implemented measures to contain COVID-19, including the closure of schools, reduction of movement and other economic activities. The coastal areas of Puntland and Somaliland were also hit by cyclone Gati in November 2020, resulting in a sharp increase in humanitarian needs which many organizations - including Oxfam Somalia - responded to. While the performance of the 2020 Gu rain was near normal, the Deyr rain of 2020 has been categorized a complete failure due to the La Nina conditions. These developments triggered severe water shortages in many regions and districts in Somalia. Since October 2020, regional administrations, communities and other humanitarian agencies have been sending alerts about looming drought conditions in many parts of Somalia.Oxfam’s feedback hotline continues to receive a high number of calls from people requesting immediate water interventions. These callers are mainly from the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. UNOCHA assessment findings indicate that over 50% of the communities in the assessed locations reported displacement of people due to water shortages, 85% raised major concerns on watershortages, and 14 out of 40 villages reported an increase in diarrheal cases. The price of water has already more than doubled. According to Oxfam’s own market assessment, one barrel of water is currently being sold at an average of USD 4.5 per barrel, with some villages reporting over USD 7 per barrel. This is forcing the most vulnerable households to travel long distances to fetch water and/or opt for poor water quality and risk their lives. The most affected communities include IDPs and low-income host communities. Women and girls are at risk of protection-related risks as they travel in search of water. Regarding COVID-19, over 4,784 cases with over 130 fatalities were registered by the WHO in Somalia since the start of the pandemic, with many cases left undetected due to asymptomatic infections, low testing capacity and the stigmatisation of COVID-19 cases among the population. The second wave of the pandemic seems to have also hit the country as the number of cases started to increase in the last few months. The government of Somaliahas eased most of the restrictions in August 2020 and most of the public services have resumed. This increases the risk of vulnerability to COVID-19 and the shortages of water in many areas further restrict the communities' ability to frequently wash their hands with soap. This might create a favourable environment for COVID-19 to spread. The Ministry of Water Development in Somaliland shareda request with all humanitarian agencies, indicating that over 196,848 people are in need of urgent water interventions and that many others also require quick rehabilitations of their water sources. Over 88% of the people in need are from the Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer regions of Eastern Somaliland. In October 2020, Oxfam using the ECHO crisis modifier budget reached the most vulnerable 1,800 HH (10,800 people) in Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer for 30 days with WASH interventions. Since then, we have continued to advocate for urgent interventions by sharing summary reports with the Somalia WASH cluster and presentations of the situation with cluster members. Utilising other existing resources, we are also working with the Ministry of Water Resources to rehabilitate boreholes that were identified as strategic wells by the government.

In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

Somalia, a fragile State that is emerging from decades of civil war, is currently experiencing an unprecedented situation mainly caused by climate change, Covid-19 and locust infestation, which exacerbated the long-term existed challenges within the country including widespread vulnerability and marginalization, insecurity and government with poor institutional capacity to deliver and advocate for basic humanitarian needs of local communities, combination of the above mentioned challenges contributed to negative socio-economic impact on Somali communities and resulted in the displacement of affected populations (mainly rural) and formation of IDP sites alongside main towns. Other challenges encountered by Somalia and Somaliland communities include lack of coping capacity to climate change and widespread dependency created by Humanitarian Aid due to the absence of government’s role that affects the livelihood of entire communities rather than building their long-term resilience. It's evident that the Humanitarian Aid Dependency has largely affected the productivity of the Somali population. However, there's need to exhaust to what extent these will be addressed by our research questions for the Participatory Action Research (PAR) on Aid Humanitarian Aid dependency. In 2019, nine Somali NGOs founded the Nexus platform that aims to shape the future in Somalia and Somaliland, by creating an enabling environment for Somali NGOs to have a leading role in the humanitarian system that puts the agency and self-reliance of communities at the center, through delivering a combination of Humanitarian Aid, Development, and Peace interventions. The Nexus coalition is led by nine Somali NGOs – African Development Solutions (ADESO), Centre for Peace and Democracy (CPD), Gargaar Relief and Development Organization (GREDO), Horn of Africa Voluntary Youth Committee (HAVOYOCO), KAALO, Save Somali Women and Children (SSWC), Social-Life and Agriculture Development Organisation (SADO), Taakulo Somaliland Community (TASCO), and WASDA. Two INGOs – Oxfam and Save the Children International were invited to join as international partners to support with critical investments. So far the platform developed and applied its strategy andtheory of change whilst Humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, Somalia Nexus consortium aims to focus interventions that are in line with its pillars, including Community-driven and working across the Triple Nexusof Development, Humanitarian Aid, Peace-building and conflict-resolution, as well as strengthening the capacity of Somali Civil Society <(>&<)> Government institutions. In addition, special considerations will be given concerning practicality and implementation methodology including presence, scaleof the need, duration and coordination with other stakeholders. The day-to-day activities of theplatform are performed by the Secretariat supported by the Steering committee who are also responsible for resource mobilization, organizing coordination meetings, fund management and drafting policies and guidelines In 2021, the Nexus platform aims to implement efforts to support its members and government institutions in both Somalia and Somaliland, through development of Community-driven Development manuals, conducting Participatory Action Research that finds durable solutions on climate related challenges in both pastoral and agro-pastoral communities, conducting PAR that aims to address the level and scope of dependency created by Unconditional Cash disbursement to local rural communities as well as supporting Somalia and Somaliland governments to develop standardized Cash Transfer model with clear guidelines. Social inclusion, protection and Covid-19 protocols will be maintained and mainstreamed in project interventions.

participating-org.narrative: It is a Somali women non-governmental humanitarian organization at a national level founded in 1992 at Mogadishu - the capital city, by a group of Somali women intellectuals from cross-section of the community. The Save Somali Women and Children (SSWC) contributeto the creation of a safe and sustainable situation by supporting women to overcome marginalization, violence and poverty in their communities. It operates as a non-profit making organization that has the right to network with a variety of organizations that share similar values and vision. In Somalia women face a range of complex challenges that require multiple solutions. We work in the belief that women through their own efforts and in collaboration with local, national and international allies are central to transforming their own lives and the lives of their communities and population of which they are part. SSWC is women-led and women-centered organization (so its programs reflect the needs of those served) that have well functioning management, finance and programmatic structures and systems.

Since 2001, AJOAGO is involved in successfully preparedness and response, improving water, sanitation and hygiene services, food security and other programmes in rural communities of Mozambique. As a result of cyclone Eloise Response that hit the district of Buzi in Sofala Province, AJOAGO, is involved in the emergency response in Buzi. The objective of this project, is to provide potable water for around 3.000 affected people in 4 accommodation centres in Buzi district in Sofala, Mozambique This project targets at least 3.000 households in Guara Guara resettlement neighbourhoods in Buzi District. Through the project these people will achieve tangible improvements in their health status, welfare and dignity through increased and sustainable access toimproved water and hygiene facilities delivery and by applying associated hygiene practices to prevent COVID 19 Pandemic.

Oxfam’s commitment is to actively centre the voice and experience of people and community in all our work and consider power, privilege and equity in the design of community-based feedback and complaints mechanisms CBFCMS, and to respect the knowledge, wisdom andperspective of others, as there is always scope for Oxfam to grow and learn as an organisation working with communities. Functionalfeedback and complaints mechanisms that are accessible and safe to use are a demonstration of our organization-wide accountability commitment, to be truly accountable to the people and communities we work with and those affected by our programmes, by ensuring that they understand what is appropriate and inappropriate conduct of our staff and partners, getting their feedback about our programmes and/or complaints about conduct of our staff, agents or partners and taking appropriate action to address these concerns. Accountability is “the process of using power responsibly, taking account of, and being held accountable by different stakeholders, and primarily those who are affected by the exercise of such power” . It is the right to be heard, and the duty to respond.
However, anecdotal information indicates that where CBFCMs initiatives and experiences exist in Oxfam, many are still disjointed, some are uncoordinated, and largely undocumented. In many places, they are non-existent, or if they are, not all of them are fully functional. The design of Oxfam’s CBFCMs by Affiliates, Country Offices and in part Partners has not always ensured community involvement, in most cases resulting in not fit for purpose mechanisms. Also different affiliates still approach the issue of CBFCMs differently with different emphasis, approaches, tools and resources, therefore lacking a standardised coordinated approach.
Although Oxfam prides itself for encouraging communities we work with to speak out and report PSEA and child protection concerns and incidents concerning them,recent reports in some countries like DRC, Ethiopia, and Uganda not only attests to the limited awareness at community level on SEAand child protection risks and reporting mechanisms, but has also led to an increase in attention to ensure that SEA and child abuse and exploitation by humanitarian and development organisations like Oxfam are addressed through investment in preventive approaches but also responding to reports of abuse and exploitation when these incidents are reported. Oxfam has two responsibilities for accountability in the programmes it manages, holding a responsibility for mutual accountability with its partners (as do the partners) and also holding a shared or joint accountability (with its partners) to the communities affected by its programmes. There is lack of knowledge how the In addition to some of the above challenges, COVID-19 has added additional challenges to how effective current CBFCMs are, placing additional barriers to reporting that are currently not fully understood or risks mitigated. OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT: 1. Map out existing CBCM’s initiatives in select field/project locations, and document best practices and lessons learnt in implementing CBFCMs across the Oxfam confederation 2. Undertake a rapid assessment of the existing CBFCMs in Oxfam terms of effectiveness, experiences and lessons plus existing gaps.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

For about a decade, the security situation in the Tillabéry region of Niger has been characterized by incursions by non-state armedgroups (NSAGs) committing abuses (abductions, forced recruitment into armed groups, extortion of valuables and money/zakat, threats, physical violence, targeted or mass killings) against the civilian population, particularly persons linked to the state or presumed to be linked to the state, thereby violating their fundamental rights. Worse, during the recent attacks, elements of GANEs systematically destroyed food stocks, shelters and extorted livestock. Cases of gender-based violence are also reported with the impositionof veils and the abduction of women and girls without ransom. This security situation, which is very worrying in the north-Malian border and in the Tri-border area (Burkina Faso-Mali-Niger), has also led to an increase in crime and banditry in the region and a deepening of the social fractures between sedentary and nomadic people, farmers and herders, and inter-ethnic rivalries, which are historical sources of tension. In addition, it has limited access to natural resources. It should be noted that the Tillabéry region, where more than 85% of households live from subsistence farming, is already among the most vulnerable in Niger. It is confronted with the recurrence of extreme climatic phenomena (drought and floods) that affect food security and the livelihoods of the population.Moreover, the last meeting of the Harmonized Framework of November 2020, estimated that nearly 15% of its population would be food insecure at some point in the year. The SMART survey reveals a prevalence of GAM among children aged 6 to 59 months of age of 9% in this region. On the other hand, the populations of the Tillabéry region also seasonally face peaks of endemic diseases such as Cholera, malaria, etc... due to inadequate WAH infrastructure and practices. Indeed, 41% of the population of Tillabéry use drinking water from unimproved sources according to the EVIAM 2020 survey. Tillabéry is also one of the regions most affected by the second wave of COVID 19. As of January 11, 2021, there were 260 confirmed cases, including 35 health workers and 16 deaths. Also, during the month of December 2020, 53 protection incidents with 83 victims were recorded in the Tillabéry region. It is in this already very fragile context that the intervention on Saturday, January 2, 2021, in the villages of Tchamobangou and Zaroumadareye - one of the most barbaric attacks ever perpetrated by GANEs against civilian populations since the beginning of this insecurity in Niger - took place.The appalling toll of this attack is 105 civilians dead, including 32 in Zaroumdarey and 73 in Tchomabongou, and 26 others wounded by gunfire. This event is said to be in retaliation for the refusal of these communities to pay the Zakat imposed by the terrorists and was mainly aimed at the able-bodied arms of the said villages. As a result, a large number of women and children are among the displaced. There is also a significant number of living stock (granaries) burned down and livestock taken away by the GANES during the attack (Report No. 28/2021/RRM/ACTED and Report of the Joint Rapid Multisectoral Mission to MANGAIZE of 12 and 13 January 2021). By the way, the identified site is that of the former Mangaizé refugee camp located on the side of a military post. With recent attacks on certain military bases in the region, in particular the tragic ones of Inates and Sinegodar with important registers registered by the national army, internally displaced persons are at risk of being caught cross-country. in case of attack on the military position of Mangaizé, potential target of terrorists. Following this attack, a joint assessment conducted by humanitarian actors with the facilitation of OCHA revealed that as of January 13, 2021, a total of 1,045 households or approximately 7,315 people had moved to Mangaize. These include forcibly displaced persons and those who have preventively left the surrounding villages. They are living with host families, already affected by a deficient agricultural season (Ouallam is one of the 17 departments of Niger exposed to severe food insecurity according to the Harmonized Framework meeting), the effects of insecurity and related security measures. In theearly hours of their arrival, their daily lives were assured thanks to the solidarity of the host populations, as well as the support of good wills and assistance provided by the Nigerien State. Relations between the host communities and the displaced are so far good. Moreover, these displaced persons are reluctant to any idea of relocation to an easily identifiable host site, fearing possible incursions by GANEs elements.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novibs main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fund raising, campaigning and advocacy. The Hub Niamey Niger exists since 2006 as a humanitarian field office and since 2012 as the decentralized Country office for Oxfam Novib, dealing with all the development and humanitarian themes like Sustainable livelihoods, Right to Basic services, Humanitarian and resilience interventions, The right to be heard and the right to an Identity, including women's rights and sexual and reproductive health rights. The Country Office in Niger works with local partners to realize the vision of a Niger without poverty

title.narrative: Supporting on Borehole Drill in Somalia

description.narrative: The eastern regions in Somaliland and especially Saanag and Sool regions continue to suffer from recurrent drought. This situation has increased the vulnerability of the communities as they have lost most of their livestock which was their main source oflivelihood. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that the two regions also continue to experience occasional inter clan fighting which isoften triggered by competition for available pasture and water resources. Drilling of the a boreholes will not only contribute to providing important water sources that can support the water needs of the communities during drought and harsh climatic conditions, but also contribute to reducing risk factors leading to conflict. It will offer an opportunity to the benefiting communities to have a chance for better access to potable water, reduce the incidents water related diseases and increase access for water for practicing frequent handwashing to prevent COVID-19. Objectives; • Provide sustainable water source for 5000 people and over 10,000 livestockheads in Sanaag Region. Groundwater Feasibility Study: A groundwater feasibility study will be conducted in three selected villagesof Sanaag region. the study will follow three approach method, 1. Remote Sensing: Desk review using latest satellite imageries to selected best possible locations. This phase will focus on finding regional fractures carrying water from highland of Ethiopia to thelowland of Sanaag regions and from Sanaag mountains to low land areas. 2. Geophysical Study: ground truthing work will be conducting using latest start of art geophysical technology at least three locations with spacing of 1000 -1500m. This location are those selected in first phase of the study work. Government and community engagement will be conducted to understand the local geology, possible impact of drilling on environment and stability of the communities. Drilling of the borehole Based on the groundwater feasibility study, the drilling work will be advertised through the local media. In order to avoid failures resulted from improper use of drilling equipment and selection of drilling method, the contractor will receive full copy of the study report and will be given a briefing on the drilling technology and technique recommended by the study team. Then, a payment by result approach will be used to contract drilling companies i.e. Oxfam/Taakulo will only pay if the borehole has water with discharge of above 2liter per second. Failureto get a contractor willing to commence drilling with such conduction, further meeting will be help between Oxfam and Taakulo to discuss best possible approach to increase value for money. Supervision and Monitoring: In drilling works supervision and monitoring progress is critical step. Oxfam/Taakulo will have a site supervisor equipped with necessary materials for supervision including TDS Sensor to record water quality at each 1 meter, mud funnel to record the drilling mud viscosity and deeper to follow the depth of the drilling. The supervisor will provide daily update to both Oxfam/Taakulo team and will ensure all decision that affect drilling performance is consulted and agreed before action. TDS level will be recorded in monitoring tool provided and the result will be used for deciding the borehole casing arrangement. All materials that will be used for drilling will be inspected by the drilling supervisor and approve. In case a specialized chemical will be used for the drilling; the supervisor will request for all safety related certificate prior use of such chemicals. Post Drilling Construction: This action will be decided right after the drilling is completed. Provision of submersible pump with cable and riser pipes, and construction of generator house, water distribution system for both animal and human and storage facilities will be included under this phase. Other grants, including ECHO 2021 and/or other internal grants will be used to finance this critical activity. Incase the borehole salinity is above an acceptable regional level i.e. 2500ppm, provision of desalination unit will be considered.

participating-org.narrative: Taakulo Somali Community Commonly known by the acronym #TASCO#. TASCO is a multifaceted non-governmental, non-profit making, non-political and non-partisan development and humanitarian aid organization established in 2007 and headquartered in Hargeisa, Somaliland. Taakulo is a Somali word meaning #helping/aiding#. Working in partnership with UN, international, and National organizations, TASCO is dedicated to helping the disadvantaged people and communities throughout Somali by engaging in development and related activities and also providing relief support and assistance, facilitating and promoting participatory local community activities and programs that emphasize human dignity and self-reliance.

Goal: Oxfam in Indonesia will transition into an affiliate organization that is leading on Inequality and Local Humanitarian Leadership in Indonesia and the wider Asia region.
Outputs: 1. Strategic development towards affiliation Oxfam Indonesia will have an independent position within the confederation upon completion of the affiliation process. The office aims to support local organizations to increase their presence by making use of the network of the confederation. The voice of Indonesian citizens and CSOs can be included in Oxfam’s advocacy and influencing work. The Indonesia office can work through networks in the region to work on influencing and advocacy.
2. Thought leadership and Knowledge Management Oxfam Indonesia will focus on advocacy work on Covid-19 and on inequality. It will establish a Knowledge Management System that can be used within the organization as well as by partner organizations. The office will support and strengthen partners’ influencing work in the humanitarian sector through the (already existing) network of SEJAJAR. This network, with now over 600 organizations, was established with two partners when Covid-19 hit the country in March 2020, to build collaborations and encourage dialogue and advocacy on Covid-19. Oxfam Indonesia will also conduct organizational learning and training, with due attention for safeguarding policies and practices in programs.
3. Partnership Academy Oxfam plans to invest in a strong partnership model that will act as a hub for a global network of partners and allies, with or without resources. ThePartnership Academy will serve to support current partner organizations to develop their organization in the area of good governance, risk management, policy development, influencing and hard skills in development and humanitarian work. This is part of Oxfam’s own exit strategy, from an Oxfam in Indonesia country office to Oxfam Indonesia, as an independent new Oxfam affiliate.

In response to the current water and food shortages caused by the ‘triple threat’ of drought, locust and COVID-19 in Eastern Somaliland, Oxfam and local partner Taakulo will support 43,800 rural IDPs and host communities (pastoralists) with integrated WASH and Food Security interventions in the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. The WASH component will reach over 43,800 people with clean drinking water and an improved and safe access to rehabilitated water sources. Existing water market structures will be sustainably strengthened through Cash for Water interventions and water prices prevented from rising by solarizing water sources and providing operators with the means to maintain existing desalination units. 1,036 households ( 6,216 women, men, boys and girls) will be supported through the food security and livelihoods assistance component. The Sida RRM will contribute to addressing the immediate food needs of the people affected by drought and the socioeconomic impact of COVID-19. Oxfam and Taakulo will respond through cash assistance that allows households to meet their basic food needs. Community and government engagement will be at the centre of the response and close engagement is ensured during the project design and implementation stages as this will increase ownership and social accountability, and ensure sustainability after our intervention ends.

In response to the current water and food shortages caused by the ‘triple threat’ of drought, locust and COVID-19 in Eastern Somaliland, Oxfam and local partner Taakulo will support 43,800 rural IDPs and host communities (pastoralists) with integrated WASH and Food Security interventions in the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer region The WASH component will reach over 43,800 people with clean drinking water and an improved and safe access to rehabilitated water sources. Existing water market structures will be sustainably strengthened through Cash for Water interventions and water prices prevented from rising by solarizing water sources and providing operators with the means to maintain existing desalination units. 1,036 households ( 6,216 women, men, boys and girls) will be supported through the food security and livelihoods assistance component. The Sida RRM will contribute to addressing the immediate food needs ofthe people affected by drought and the socioeconomic impact of COVID-19. Oxfam and Taakulo will respond through cash assistance that allows households to meet their basic food needs. Community and government engagement will be at the centre of the response and close engagement is ensured during the project design and implementation stages as this will increase ownership and social accountability, and ensure sustainability after our intervention ends.

participating-org.narrative: Taakulo Somali Community Commonly known by the acronym #TASCO#. TASCO is a multifaceted non-governmental, non-profit making, non-political and non-partisan development and humanitarian aid organization established in 2007 and headquartered in Hargeisa, Somaliland. Taakulo is a Somali word meaning #helping/aiding#. Working in partnership with UN, international, and National organizations, TASCO is dedicated to helping the disadvantaged people and communities throughout Somali by engaging in development and related activities and also providing relief support and assistance, facilitating and promoting participatory local community activities and programs that emphasize human dignity and self-reliance.

description.narrative: Based on the congestion/limitations of the old city port and the existing Thilawa port and taken into account the growing transport needs to cater for domestic purposes and trade to West China, it is expected that the city ports and the actual Yangon river navigation capacity will reach its limits by 2027-2030 (depending on COVID-19 recovery). The Yangon Region Government (YRG) therefore intends to develop new port facilities towards the sea on the West Bank of the Yangon River. These new facilities are designated as a location to which the existing Yangon city ports are to be relocated (strategic objective), but will also provide necessary capacity and cost reduction on the short-term (as inner ports will be relocated gradually). By shifting the inner ports, the vessel turnaround time will be reduced as the port would be closer to the sea and the dredging expenses spending on inner shallow areas will be saved too. The map below provides an overview of the port locations in Yangon, indicating the two current port locations (City Port Area and Thilawa Port) and the intended relocation of the City Port Area (New West Bank Port).

WASH Officer UNHCR Cameroon – Supporting the provision of WASG services to persons of concern to UNHCR. This includes ensuring that an adequate level of water service is provided at each site in accordance with applicable UNHCR and National Standard and in line with addressing the global Covid-19 pillars of activities in regard to (1) risk communication and community engagement – WASH awareness and hygiene promotion, (2) infection prevention and control – access to adequate WASH services to institutions and households, (3) operational support and logistics – ensure enough contingency stocks according to standards.
